TextView.android:text: 1)In electrical resistance welding material of electrode should have

RadioButton.android:text: C)sufficient strength to sustain high pressure at elevated temperatures.

TextView.android:text: View Answer

Answer : Option D 
 In resistance welding, heat is generated in localized area which is enough to heat the 
 metal to sufficient temperature, so that the parts can be joined with the application of 
 pressure. Pressure is applied through the electrodes. So to achieve this, the material of the 
 electrode should have higher electrical and thermal conductivities with sufficient strength 
 to sustain high pressure at elevated temperatures.
2)The metal surfaces for electrical resistance welding must be
View Answer

Answer : Option B 
 The metal surfaces should be properly cleaned so that they are free from rust, dust, oil 
 and grease. For this purpose metal surfaces may be given pickling treatment i.e. dipping 
 in diluted acid bath and then washing in hot water bath and then in the cold water bath. 
 After that surfaces may be dried through the jet of compressed air. If surfaces are rust free 
 then pickling is not required but surface cleaning can be done through some solvent such 
 as acetone to remove oil and grease.
3)Radiation from a body is proportional to
View Answer

Answer : Option B 
 According to Stephens law, 
 Where T1 = temperature of the source of heat, 
 and T2 = temperature of the substance to be heated.
4)Induction heating takes place in

RadioButton.android:text: B)conducting materials which may be either magnetic or non-magentic materials.

TextView.android:text: View Answer

Answer : Option B 
 In induction heating, the effect of currents induced by electromagnetic action in the charge is employed 
 The heat developed depends on the power drawn by charge. 
 The power consequently depends upon the voltage and resistance of charge. 
 So for the developed heat to sufficiently melt the charge, the resistance of the charge must be low, 
 which is possible only with metals and voltage must be high, which is obtained by 
 employing higher flux and higher frequency. 
 Therefore magnetic material can be easily treated than non-magnetic materials because of their higher permeability. 
 So induction heating takes place in conducting materials that may be magnetic or non magnetic materials.
5)The main advantage of dielectric heating is that

RadioButton.android:text: A)heating occurs in the material itself.
B)heating occurs due to high frequency.
C)it can be used for drying the explosives.

TextView.android:text: View Answer

Answer : Option A 
 When an insulting material is subjected to an alternating electric field, the atoms get 
 stresses and due to the inter atomic friction heat is produced. This loss in known as 
 dielectric loss. Hence the main advantages of dielectric heating is that heating occurs in 
 the material itself.
6)The supply frequency usually employed for high frequency eddy current heating is
View Answer

Answer : Option D 
 Eddy current losses do not follow f2 law as frequency is increased higher and higher. At 
 10 KHz, the total heating may vary directly as the frequency and even drop to one half 
 power at frequencies of order of 500 KHz.
7)The most modern method for food processing is
View Answer
Answer : Option B \n Dielectric heating has been applied in the food processing industry:
8)In induction heating

RadioButton.android:text: A)magnetic materials can be easily treated in comparison to non-magnetic materials.
B) heat is produced due to current induced in the charge by electromagnetic action.
C)the resistance of charge must be low and voltage applied must be high in order to produce sufficient heat.

TextView.android:text: View Answer

Answer : Option D 
 In induction heating, heat is produced due to current induced in the charge by 
 electromagnetic action. To develop heat sufficient to melt the charge, the resistance of the 
 charge must be low and voltage applied must be high because of the power drawn in 
 induction heating is equal of V2/R. In induction heating, magnetic can be easily treated in 
 comparison to non magnetic materials because of their high permeability.
9)In an electric room heat converter the method of heating used is
View Answer

Answer : Option C 
 An electric room heat converter is a heater which operates by air covection currents 
 circulating through the body of the appliacne and across its heating elements. The 
 resistance heating is provided to it. This heats up the air, causing it to increase it to 
 increase in volume and so become buoyant and rise.
10)In induction heating, the depth up to which current will penetrate is proportional to
View Answer
Answer : Option C \n
11) _______________ is not an applictaion of dielectric heat.
View Answer

Answer : Option B \n Soldering at high temperatures or brazzing where silver, copper, their, alloys arc used as solders is another important industruial application. Two pieces of metal arc firred properly and suitable flux is applied to the joint and the soldering alloy is placed near the joint. By induction heating heat develops very rapidly melting the solder which runs into the joint sealing it properly.
12)The dielectric loss in a dielectric is proportional to

RadioButton.android:text: B)The square of the voltage impressed on the dielectric.
C) Square root of the voltage impressed on the dielectric.

TextView.android:text: View Answer

Answer : Option B \n Dielectric loss in a dielectric is given as \n From the equation, P ∝ V2. Hence, we can say that dielectric loss proportional to the square of the voltage impressed on the dielectric.
13) The power factor will be leading in case of
View Answer

Answer : Option C \n In dielectric heating, the current is drawn by the capacitor. When an AC supply voltage is applied across the capacitor plates, the current does lead the supply voltage by exactly 90° and there is always an in-phase component of the current. Since the dielectric heating is involved the capacitor , So the power factor will be leading in the case of dielectric heating. The value of power factor for a particular non-conducting material is constant.
14)For dielectric heating the range of frequency normally employed is
View Answer

Answer : Option D \n In dielectric heating, for producing sufficient heat frequency is used between 10 MHz and 30 MHz. Dielectric heating depend upon the value of frequency. Hence to achieve more heat, high frequency is used.
15)The method of heating used for non conducting materials is
View Answer

Answer : Option B \n When non conducting parts such as wood, plastics, bones are subjected to dielectric heating, an alternative electrostatic field dielectric loss occurs. In dielectric heating use of these losses is made.
16)The advantage(s) of eddy current heating is/are

RadioButton.android:text: A)easy temperature control, little wastage of heat.
B)heat can made to penetrate into metal surface to any desired depth.
D)the area of surface over which the heat is produced can be accurately controlled.

TextView.android:text: View Answer

Answer : Option C 
 The advantages of eddy current heating are 
 1)It is quick, clean and convenient method.
 2) The control of temperature is very easy. 
 3)The heat can made to penetrate into the metal surface to any desired depth. 
 4) The area of surface over which heat is produced can be accurately controlled. 
 5) It can easily take place in vacuum or any other special atmosphere. There is little wastage of heat, as heat is produced in the body to be heated up directly.
17)The method appropriate for heating of non ferrous materials is
View Answer
Answer : Option D \n Due to indirect arc heating, a furnace becomes suitable for comparatively low melting point. So these furnaces are used for melting non ferrous metal.
18) For arc furnaces low voltage high current power supply is needed because

RadioButton.android:text: A) life of the roof refractory is increased.
B)maximum secondary voltage is limited to 275 V (line to line voltage open circuit voltage).
C) heavy current produces large amount of heat resulting in higher temperature.

TextView.android:text: View Answer

Answer : Option D 
 The reasons for employing low voltage high current power supply for arc furnace arc as follows: 
 1) Heating effect is proportional to the square of the current, therefore, to achieve higher temperature high current is essential. 
 2) The maximum secondary voltage is also limited to 275 V (line to line open circuit voltage) because of insulation and safety considerations. 
 3) By using low voltage and high current the electrodes are kept very near to change as the arc is of small length. Thus arc remains away from the roof and therefore, life of roof refractory is increased. 
 Higher voltage causes higher voltage gradient between the electrodes and the charge, causing the nitrogen furnace atmosphere ionised and absorbed by the charge, which produces embrittlement.
19)The simplest and most common used method for temperature control is

RadioButton.android:text: A)change of connections of heating circuit .
B) use of variable number of heating elements.
D) using external series resistance of heating elements.

TextView.android:text: View Answer

Answer : Option A \n In change of connections method, the elements are arranged in such a way that all the elements can be connected either in series or in parallel or in series-parallel combination or in star or in delta by means of switches at different instants according to the requirements. This method is simplest and most commonly used method of temperature control.
20)On increasing the thickness of the refractory wall of the furnace

RadioButton.android:text: A)temperature inside the furnace will drop.
B)temperature on the outer surface of furnace walls will drop.
D)heat loss through furnace walls will increase.

TextView.android:text: View Answer

Answer : Option B \n In a furnace, the temperature gradients are across the thickness of the wall. So if the thickness increases, the temperature on the outer walls will decrease due to conduction phenomenon.
